SENT.plain: Antithyroid drugs have been used for more than 50 years for the management of hyperthyroidism
Most patients tolerate treatment well but some may develop life-threatening side effects such as agranulocytosis, aplastic anemia and cholestatic hepatitis
A 45-year-old female was diagnosed with severe hyperthyroidism
Treatment with Carbimazole 30 mg/day was initiated
Within six weeks following the start of therapy, patient developed potentially life-threatening acute cholestatic hepatitis and agranulocytosis as adverse effects to carbimazole
The patient's symptoms and laboratory abnormalities resolved following withdrawal of offending drug
Agranulocytosis and cholestatic hepatitis together is an extremely rare idiosyncratic side effect of Carbimazole treatment and considered to be dose and age-related

Antithyroid drugs are deceptively easy to use, but because of the variability in the response of patients and the potentially serious side effects, all practitioners who prescribe the drugs need to have a working knowledge of their complex pharmacology
